Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I stared at my calendar, the team meeting reminder blinking at me. As a colleague, I was expected to join, share updates, and show I was part of the team—even if today’s meeting was just a routine catch-up and would be recorded for anyone who missed it. But as a telemarketer, my phone was already ringing with prospects curious about our new service. Lately, they’d been asking technical questions that went way beyond my script. My manager expected me to handle these objections smoothly, keep the calls moving, and not let anyone slip away. I felt the pressure mounting: if I joined the meeting, I’d miss live calls and risk losing leads; if I stayed on the phones, I’d look disengaged to my team. My mind raced, torn between being a reliable colleague and a high-performing telemarketer, knowing that whichever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
